title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0001
text: What is the root interface of the Java Collections Framework?
explanation: The Collection interface is the root interface of the Java Collections Framework hierarchy.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0002
text: Which package contains the Collection interface?
explanation: The Collection interface is part of the java.util package.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0003
text: Which of the following interfaces directly extends Collection?
explanation: List, Set, and Queue are the main subinterfaces that extend the Collection interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0004
text: Which of the following is NOT a method in the Collection interface?
explanation: The put() method belongs to the Map interface, not Collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0005
text: Which of the following methods is used to add all elements from another collection?
explanation: The addAll() method adds all elements from another collection to the current collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0006
text: Which of the following methods removes all elements from a collection?
explanation: The clear() method removes all elements from the collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0007
text: Which of the following methods checks if a collection is empty?
explanation: The isEmpty() method returns true if the collection contains no elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0008
text: Which of the following methods returns the number of elements in a collection?
explanation: The size() method returns the number of elements in the collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0009
text: Which of the following methods checks if a specific element exists in a collection?
explanation: The contains() method checks if a specific element exists in the collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0010
text: Which of the following methods converts a collection into an array?
explanation: The toArray() method converts the collection into an array.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0011
text: Which of the following methods removes a specific element from a collection?
explanation: The remove() method removes a specific element from the collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0012
text: Which of the following methods retains only the elements that are also contained in another collection?
explanation: The retainAll() method retains only the elements that are also contained in another collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0013
text: Which of the following methods removes all elements that are also contained in another collection?
explanation: The removeAll() method removes all elements that are also contained in another collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0014
text: Which of the following methods returns an iterator over the elements in a collection?
explanation: The iterator() method returns an iterator over the elements in the collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0015
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface?

options.text: It defines basic operations for all collections

explanation: The Collection interface defines basic operations such as add, remove, and iteration for all collections.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and null elements?
explanation: Some implementations like ArrayList allow null elements, while others like TreeSet do not.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and duplicates?
explanation: Some implementations like List allow duplicates, while others like Set do not.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and ordering?
explanation: Some implementations like List maintain order, while others like HashSet do not.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0019
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and synchronization?

options.text: Collection interface itself is not synchronized
Collection interface is synchronized by default

explanation: The Collection interface is not synchronized by default; synchronization is provided by wrapper methods.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0020
text: Which of the following methods was added to the Collection interface in Java 8?
explanation: The stream() method was added in Java 8 to support functional-style operations on collections.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0021
text: Which of the following methods was introduced in Java 8 for bulk operations?
explanation: The forEach() method was introduced in Java 8 to perform actions for each element using lambda expressions.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0022
text: Which of the following methods returns a Spliterator for the collection?
explanation: The spliterator() method returns a Spliterator that can be used for parallel iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0023
text: Which of the following methods was added in Java 8 to remove elements based on a condition?
explanation: The removeIf() method removes all elements that satisfy a given predicate condition.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and generics?
explanation: The Collection interface is generic and can hold objects of any specified type.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and immutability?

options.text: Collections can be made unmodifiable using Collections.unmodifiableCollection()

explanation: Collections can be made unmodifiable using the Collections.unmodifiableCollection() method.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0026
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and thread safety?

options.text: Collections can be synchronized using Collections.synchronizedCollection()
All collections are thread-safe by default

explanation: Collections can be synchronized using the Collections.synchronizedCollection() method.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and iteration?

options.text: Collection provides an iterator() method for traversal

explanation: The iterator() method provides a way to traverse elements in a collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and equality?

options.text: The equals() method compares collections based on elements
The equals() method compares memory addresses
The equals() method is not defined in Collection
The equals() method compares hash codes only

explanation: The equals() method compares two collections based on their elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and hashCode()?

options.text: hashCode() returns a hash based on the elements in the collection
hashCode() is not defined in Collection
hashCode() returns the size of the collection

explanation: The hashCode() method returns a hash code based on the elements in the collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and streams?

options.text: Collection provides stream() and parallelStream() methods

explanation: The Collection interface provides stream() and parallelStream() methods for stream processing.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and functional programming?

options.text: Collection supports functional operations like forEach and removeIf
Collection does not support functional operations

explanation: The Collection interface supports functional operations introduced in Java 8 such as forEach and removeIf.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and type safety?

options.text: Generics provide type safety in collections
Collections can store only Object type
Collections can store only primitive types

explanation: Generics ensure type safety by restricting the type of elements stored in a collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and null elements?
explanation: Some implementations like ArrayList allow null elements, while others like TreeSet do not.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and duplicates?
explanation: Some implementations like List allow duplicates, while others like Set do not.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and ordering?
explanation: Some implementations like List maintain order, while others like HashSet do not.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and fail-fast behavior?

options.text: Iterators of most collections are fail-fast

explanation: Iterators of most collections are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and bulk operations?

options.text: Collection supports bulk operations like addAll, removeAll, retainAll

explanation: The Collection interface supports bulk operations such as addAll, removeAll, and retainAll.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and toArray()?

options.text: toArray() converts the collection into an array
toArray() converts the collection into a list
toArray() converts the collection into a map
toArray() converts the collection into a set

explanation: The toArray() method converts the collection into an array.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and removeIf()?

options.text: removeIf() removes elements that satisfy a given condition

explanation: The removeIf() method removes elements that satisfy a given predicate condition.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and stream processing?

options.text: Collection supports stream processing via stream() and parallelStream()
Collection does not support stream processing

explanation: The Collection interface supports stream processing through stream() and parallelStream() methods.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and default methods?

options.text: Java 8 introduced default methods like stream() and removeIf()
Default methods were introduced in Java 7

explanation: Java 8 introduced default methods in interfaces, including stream() and removeIf() in Collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and inheritance?

options.text: List, Set, and Queue extend Collection

explanation: List, Set, and Queue are subinterfaces of the Collection interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and Map?

options.text: Map is a subtype of Collection

explanation: Map is not part of the Collection hierarchy; it is a separate interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and iteration order?

options.text: Iteration order depends on the implementation
Iteration order is always insertion order

explanation: Iteration order depends on the specific implementation, such as ArrayList or HashSet.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and modification?

options.text: Collection supports adding and removing elements

explanation: The Collection interface supports adding and removing elements through methods like add() and remove().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and size?

options.text: The size() method returns the number of elements
The size() method returns the capacity
The size() method returns the hash code
The size() method returns the index

explanation: The size() method returns the number of elements in the collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and isEmpty()?

options.text: isEmpty() returns true if the collection has no elements
isEmpty() returns false if the collection has no elements
isEmpty() returns the size of the collection
isEmpty() throws an exception if empty

explanation: The isEmpty() method returns true if the collection contains no elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and containsAll()?

options.text: containsAll() checks if all elements of another collection are present

explanation: The containsAll() method checks if all elements of another collection are present in the current collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about the Collection interface and removeAll()?

options.text: removeAll() removes all elements that are also in another collection

explanation: The removeAll() method removes all elements that are also contained in another collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkCollection - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes the Collection interface?

options.text: A root interface that defines basic operations for all collection types
An interface that defines key-value pairs
An interface that defines only sorting operations
An interface that defines only iteration

explanation: The Collection interface is the root interface that defines basic operations for all collection types in Java.
